header.title: A Parapsychological Investigation of the I Ching: Seeking Psi in an Ancient Chinese System of Divination

central_thesis: This paper investigates the I Ching through a parapsychological lens, attempting to replicate previous findings that suggest paranormal (psi) effects are involved in its operation and that certain personality traits correlate with success in I Ching-based psi tasks. It specifically tests hexagram hitting rates and changing line generation, and their relationships with transliminality and 16PF personality factors, using both a new sample and pooled data from prior studies.

structure_content.summary: The paper introduces the I Ching as a divination system used in two prior studies by Storm & Thalbourne (1998-1999, 2001a). These studies involved participants generating hexagrams and changing lines using coins, with significant 'hexagram hitting' rates found above chance. The current paper describes a third study and re-analysis of pooled data (N=243) to further investigate psi and psychological correlations.

This section outlines the formal I Ching consultation process (posing a question, throwing coins six times for hexagrams and changing lines). It details Storm and Thalbourne's 'unorthodox' experimental protocol, which simplifies the I Ching process for empirical testing by providing a single question for all participants and focusing on two paranormal tasks: matching an outcome hexagram to one of 16 selections ('hitting') and generating changing lines. It also describes prior findings on correlations with 16PF factors and transliminality.

The paper proposes nine hypotheses. Six parapsychological hypotheses predict above-chance hexagram hitting, positive relationships between transliminality and both hitting/changing lines, and specific correlations between hitting/changing lines and 16PF factors or 'belief in psi' questions. Three psychological hypotheses predict positive correlations between transliminality and belief in psi, as well as specific 16PF factors.

Forty-three psychology II students participated (81% female, mean age 21). Measures included an I Ching hexagram descriptor form (with questions on prior use and belief in psi), the 29-item Transliminality Scale (Form B), Cattell's 16PF (testing relevant factors), and Storm's 'pro attitude scale'. Apparatus included Australian 10-cent coins, a coin cup, a felt-lined box, and various instruction/score sheets.

Participants attended one of three sessions, read an information sheet, signed consent, and completed the I Ching Hexagram Descriptor Form. They chose 16 two-word descriptors, then threw three coins six times to generate an outcome hexagram. Changing lines were also recorded. Hexagrams were decoded by the experimenter. Participants then completed the Transliminality Scale and 16PF. Hits and misses were determined later, unknown to participants at the time.

For the N=43 sample, hexagram hitting was above chance but not significant (Pobs=.26, p=.535). Most parapsychological correlations were non-significant, except hitting with Factor Q4 (Tension) which was significant but in the opposite direction. Psychological hypotheses showed transliminality correlated positively and significantly with 'sheep' and 'super-sheep' questions, and significant correlations with 16PF Factors M, TM, and SC. For the N=243 pooled sample, hexagram hitting was significantly above chance (Pobs=.32, p=.007). Most parapsychological and all psychological hypotheses were significantly confirmed, with some marginal significance.

Post hoc analysis showed pro attitude scores correlated positively with belief in psi. Specific correlations, like hitting/Factor Q2 and hitting/Factor H, were examined across studies, showing inconsistency. The discussion acknowledges the disappointing results of the N=43 study (attributed to rushed conditions and lack of rapport) but concludes that the pooled data (N=243) supports the I Ching experiment as a reasonably reliable means of testing psi. It suggests certain personality types are more likely to elicit psi and highlights the value of a process-oriented approach. Future research needs to refine 'pro attitude' measurement and address the observed weakening of effects across studies.

key_concepts.definition: An ancient Chinese book of divination, used here as a system for generating symbols (hexagrams) for empirical parapsychological investigation.

A six-line symbol, generated in the experiment by throwing three coins six times. Each throw produces a 'yin' or 'yang' line. Participants aim to 'hit' a pre-selected descriptor corresponding to an outcome hexagram.
Lines produced when coin throws result in three-of-a-kind (HHH or TTT), which generate a second hexagram with an associated extra reading. These were tested for psi influence.

In the context of the experiment, this refers to a match between the participant's generated outcome hexagram and one of their 16 previously selected hexagram descriptor-pairs, indicating a successful psi effect.
Defined as the 'hypothesised tendency for psychological material to cross (trans) thresholds (limines) into or out of consciousness' (Thalbourne & Houran, 2000, p. 853), measured by a 29-item scale.
A personality test (Cattell, Eber, & Tatsuoka, 1970) used to measure primary components of personality, with specific factors correlated with psi performance.
Paranormal effects being investigated, potentially including precognition (predicting the outcome hexagram) or psychokinesis (influencing coin throws).
A scale designed to measure how much participants desire or are interested in scoring a 'hit' in the experiment.
A question asking participants if they believe it is possible for at least some people to exhibit paranormal effects in the experiment.
A question asking participants if they believe in their own abilities to exhibit paranormal effects in the experiment.

practical_system.description: This paper describes an experimental methodology adapted from the I Ching divination system to investigate paranormal phenomena (psi). It is not a practical manual for traditional I Ching consultation, but rather an 'unorthodox' protocol designed to level the playing field for participants by removing the need for personal questions and focusing on empirical testing of hexagram generation and changing lines for psi effects.
tools: A coin cup for shaking coins
A felt-lined box as a receptacle for falling coins
An 'I Ching hexagram file' containing an introductory page, how-to-score page, and 64 hexagram readings (including changing line readings)
A score record sheet for logging coin throws and outcomes
A 'how to generate an I Ching hexagram' instruction sheet
An 'eight by eight (8 × 8) trigram matrix' for hexagram calculation
An I Ching Hexagram Descriptor Form for participant selections and belief questions
rituals: Participants select 16 two-word descriptors from a provided list, representing hexagrams they feel are relevant to their current state.
Participants throw three Australian 10-cent coins six times using a coin cup, recording the number of heads and tails for each throw on a score sheet.
Each throw's outcome (e.g., HHT, HHH, TTT) is converted into a 'yin' or 'yang' line, building a hexagram from bottom to top.
If three-of-a-kind (HHH or TTT) occurs, a 'changing line' is generated, leading to a second hexagram. These are specifically observed as a potential psi manifestation.
The experimenter decodes the hexagrams using an 8x8 trigram matrix to identify the final outcome hexagram and determines 'hits' by matching it against the participant's initial 16 selections.

relevant_quotes.text: The Chinese book of divination, the I Ching, has been used in two studies that featured an unorthodox use of the system (L. Storm & M. A. Thalbourne, 1998-1999, 2001a). Both studies (N₁ = 93; N₂ = 107), tested participants on 2 paranormal tasks using 3 coins: (a) generation of a hexagram (a six-line symbol with associated reading or 'fortune'), and (b) generation of changing lines (gained by throwing 3-of-a-kind using 3 coins). The hexagram hit-rates (i.e., ‘hitting') in both studies were significantly above chance, but the number of changing lines in both studies was not.

Formally, to consult the 'oracle' of the I Ching, one must generate one of 64 hexagrams, which involves: (i) posing a meaningful (sensible) question to the I Ching, and (ii) throwing three coins, six times, to generate the hexagram and its corresponding reading. (Each throw of the coins produces one of the six 'yin' or 'yang' lines, so that, throw by throw, the hexagram is built from the bottom up.) The coins may show three-of-a-kind on some occasions, and these throws produce so-called changing lines, which generate a second hexagram with an associated extra reading.
Transliminality, the 'hypothesised tendency for psychological material to cross (trans) thresholds (limines) into or out of consciousness' (Thalbourne & Houran, 2000, p. 853).

Storm and Thalbourne described their own I Ching experiment as "unorthodox" (Storm & Thalbourne, 1998–1999, p. 106). Their protocol necessarily 'leveled the playing field' for all participants by subjecting them all to one and the same question for the I Ching, thereby eliminating the need for the formation of a personal question.
Hypothesis 1: Hexagram hitting, when expressed as a proportion of hits, is at a rate greater than mean chance expectation (i.e., MCE; PMCE = .25; binomial test).

The third I Ching experiment using only 43 participants has produced extremely disappointing results. It is important, though, to recognise that this experiment was a rather rushed affair... Nevertheless, the results of eight planned hypotheses, as tested using the data from three pooled samples (total N = 243), in conjunction with the success rates presented above, suggest that this implementation of the I Ching experiment may continue to be a reasonably reliable means of testing psi.

critical_analysis.relevance: This paper is highly relevant to Western Esotericism, Occultism, and Magic, particularly for those interested in divination systems and the empirical investigation of 'anomalous' phenomena. While presenting a parapsychological study rather than a magical grimoire, it probes the mechanics of the I Ching, a revered divinatory tool across cultures. Its 'unorthodox' approach, aiming to isolate and measure psi effects, offers a unique perspective on the underlying mechanisms often attributed to esoteric practices. Practitioners may find validation for their experiences in the findings of above-chance hexagram hitting in pooled data, while academics benefit from the systematic attempt to quantify and correlate psi with personality traits (transliminality, 16PF factors), bridging psychology and occult studies. The self-critique regarding experimental conditions and the call for deeper understanding of 'pro attitude' also reflect a nuanced engagement with the complexities of magical/psi operations.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience includes academic parapsychologists, psychologists specializing in personality and anomalous experiences, and researchers interested in the empirical study of divination. A secondary audience comprises occult practitioners, esotericists, and mages who utilize the I Ching or other divinatory systems, providing an empirical lens through which to understand potential operative mechanisms, even if the study's 'unorthodox' method deviates from traditional ritual practice.
